greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) is the largest proper divisor d of n such that A048720(d,k) = n for some k.
comment: For n > 1, a(n) is the largest proper divisor d of n for which it holds that when the binary expansion of d is converted to a (0,1)-polynomial (e.g., 13=1101[2] encodes X^3 + X^2 + 1), then that polynomial is a divisor of (0,1)-polynomial similarly converted from n, when the polynomial division is done over field GF(2). See the example.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
Antti Karttunen, Data supplement: n, a(n) computed for n = 1..65537
Index entries for sequences related to polynomials in ring GF(2)[X]
example: For n = 39 = 3*13, A032742(39) = 13, but 13 is not the answer because X^3 + X^2 + 1 does not divide X^5 + X^2 + X + 1 (39 is "100111" in binary) over GF(2). However, the next smaller divisor 3 works because X^5 + X^2 + X + 1 = (X^1 + 1)(X^4 + X^3 + X^2 + 1) when multiplication is done over GF(2). Note that 39 = A048720(3,29), where 29 is "11101" in binary. Thus a(39) = 3.
program: (PARI) A325563(n) = if(1==n,n, my(p = Pol(binary(n))*Mod(1, 2)); fordiv(n,d,if((d>1),my(q = Pol(binary(n/d))*Mod(1, 2)); if(0==(p%q), return(n/d)))));
xref: Cf. A325559 (positions of ones, after the initial 1).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, May 11 2019
